conclusion: The light source is in front of the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
Each object casts a shadow corresponding to its shape and position.
The light source moves backward (away from the objects).
This changes the angle at which light hits the objects, affecting the shadows.
Shadows will shift backward in the direction of the light source's movement.
Shadows will become shorter as the light source moves backward.
Shadow A (Cylinder) will shift backward and the size will reduce, becoming less elongated.
Shadow B (Rectangular Block) will shift backward and the size will reduce.
Shadow C (Cylindrical Object) will shift backward and the size will reduce.
Shadow D (Paper Airplane) will shift backward and the size will reduce.
The primary effect is that all shadows move backward and become shorter.
When the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become shorter.
The changes in position and size will be consistent for each shadow due to the uniform backward movement of the light source.
